title: How do mobile phones emit radiation? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, they’d BETTER, or they wouldn’t be of much use. Here’s the problem: people are so frightened by that word “radiation” that no one stops to think about just what it means. “Radiation” simply means the transmission of energy through space or some medium; it covers heat, light, radio waves, TV signals, and pretty much any case where energy is getting from here to there without physical contact or motion (and even there, if you want to consider sound as “acoustic radiation,” things get muddy). Not all “radiation” is at all dangerous, and with those forms that can be dangerous, it is (as is the case with so many things) the dose that makes all the difference. “Dangerous” radiation in this context generally means ionizing radiation - those forms, like X-rays and gamma rays, that are energetic enough to break chemical bonds and strip the electrons off atoms (“ionizing” them, hence the name). This is the sort of radiation that, if you get enough of it, causes radiation sickness, cancer, and a whole host of nasty things. But the vast majority of things we class as “radiation” are NOT of this type. Ordinary radio waves, for example. Visible light. Infrared “light” (the sort we most commonly associate with heat). And so forth. Cell phones, in particular, emit the following sorts of “radiation:: Light. Ordinary ol’ light, coming from the screen, and obviously not a LOT of that (take a phone out in the sunlight, and you can barely read it - because sunlight is orders of magnitude more intense than the maximum light the screen can produce).Heat. The phone warms up as you use it, because the electronics dissipate power. This results in the radiation of infrared light (and below), but again, it’s just not that much. (And unless you think IR light can cause any health issues, it’s nothing to worry about. If you DO think IR causes health issues, then you’ve got a LOT more to worry about than your cell phone). And finally:Radio waves. Obviously, the phone is communicating with the cell system, with Bluetooth devices, with Wi-Fi networks - and all of this happens using radio waves. These are of even lower frequencies (longer wavelengths), and so lower energies, than either the infrared or visible light output, and so these are also non-ionizing, low-power, and nothing to worry about.So yes, cell phones radiate. But no, it’s not any sort of “bad radiation.”

Radio waves, the radios they use to communicate with the cell towers, are a form of radiation. As is visible light, the infra-red emitted from a stove, microwaves in your cooker, WiFi, broadcast TV and radio, and a lot more. The more energetic the radiation (the higher the frequency), the more dangerous it is. The radios used by cellphones are very low energy. Apart from anything else, the batteries that power them do not have enough power to emit anything harmful effects for more than a minute or two. Worries about harmful radiation from cellphones are pure superstition. There have been large scale studies, and no damage has been found.
